abstract:
In order to ensure the conservation of wildlife habitats under the Northwest Power Planning Act, the Bonneville Power Administration (BPA) uses a method called Habitat Evaluation Procedure (HEP). This approach, developed by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, uses models to assess the quality of specific habitats for target wildlife species. These models are based on key habitat parameters such as shrub height, snag density, or distance to water. The method provides a quantitative evaluation of habitat quality, known as Habitat Units (HUs), where one acre of optimum habitat equals one HU. This accounting system helps determine the amount of credit BPA receives for protected lands.

Although HSI models were initially used to evaluate the baseline condition of areas like the Precious Lands, long-term monitoring is now conducted using HEP data collection procedures. Surveys and transects are utilized to assess plant community health, weed encroachment, limiting factors for wildlife, and identify areas of habitat degradation. Properly trained personnel and consistent revisiting of transects at the same time of year and phenological stage ensure accurate data collection.

The necessity of HEP lies in its ability to provide a systematic, standardized approach to measure and monitor habitat quality over time. This is essential for understanding the impact of human activities on wildlife habitats, identifying areas that require intervention, and ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements. By using this method, we can gain valuable insights into plant community health trends, weed encroachment patterns, and limiting factors for wildlife populations.

description:
The Northwest Power Planning Act requires the Bonneville Power Administration (BPA) to offset wildlife habitat losses through various projects, including the Precious Lands project. To assess and quantify these habitat changes, BPA employs the Habitat Evaluation Procedure (HEP), a habitat modeling strategy developed by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. HEP utilizes models based on key habitat parameters, such as shrub height or snag density, to evaluate the quality of specific habitats for target wildlife species.

The result of this evaluation is a quantitative measure called a Habitat Unit (HU), where one acre of optimum habitat equals one HU. This HU accounting system determines the amount of credit BPA receives for land protection. For initial evaluations, the Habitat Suitability Index (HSI) models were used to assess the baseline condition of the Precious Lands Area.

Long-term monitoring is conducted using HEP data collection procedures, which may not be limited to particular wildlife variables. For instance, in grasslands, percent microbiotic crust cover and percent bare ground are recorded for microplots, while in riparian and conifer cover types, the number of woody debris greater than 4 diameter is recorded for transects. Surveys will be used to assess long-term trends in plant community health, identify weedy encroachment, determine limiting factors for wildlife, and monitor areas of habitat degradation.

Proper training of personnel in HEP monitoring techniques and local flora identification is crucial. Repeated transect runs should occur at the same time of year and phenological stage as the baseline transects to ensure consistent and accurate data collection.

The primary objectives of long-term monitoring include developing trend data for plant community health and weed encroachment, identifying limiting factors for wildlife, and monitoring areas of habitat degradation. By following these practices, BPA can effectively measure and mitigate the impact of its activities on wildlife habitats under the Northwest Power Planning Act.
